text.p: Oshkosh Truck Corp said it is repositioned for long-term growth and has focused its resources on fire and emergency, defense and commercial vehicles for 1997.

"While our fiscal 1996 earnings are quite disappointing, we have repositioned the company for sustainable long-term earnings growth," said chairman/chief executive officer Eugene Goodson late on Tuesday in an earnings statement. "To improve long-term earnings, we are now focused on our three vehicle businesses of fire and emergency, defense and commercial trucks."
Oshkosh Truck on Tuesday reported a net loss for the 1996 fiscal year of $3.1 million, or $0.35 per share, compared to net income of $9.2 million, or $1.04 per share for 1995.
The 1996 results included an $11.3 million in after-tax charges and after-tax benefits of $2.0 million on reversal of income tax provisions and related accrued interest.

For the fourth quarter ended Sept 30, 1996, it reported a net loss of $2.3 million, or $0.26 per share, on net sales of $118 million. During the same 1995 period, it had net income of $3.3 million of $0.36 a share on net sales of $109 million.

The company said its board on November 18 decided to no longer rely on an alliance formed in June 1995 between Oshkosh Truck and Freightliner Corp, which it said "had not achieved any of its objectives and was not likely to do so." It said the firms are negotiating to continue supplying some components and systems to each other.

Goodson also said Oshkosh Truck's acquisition in September 1996 of Pierce Manufacturing Inc provides a "leading position in the U.S. fire apparatus industry and a strong distribution system for Oshkosh's commercial products."
He called Pierce sales since the acquisition "outstanding" and said the company is achieving its cost-reduction targets.
